page.title: Pronouns - As a Nominal Phrase
page.introduction: Pronouns normally stand alone in the place of an entire nominal phrase, but they can also be modified by a partitive phrase and in some languages pronouns may be modified by determiners and quantifiers. English examples of this type include the following:
In fewer languages, these elements can also be modified by adjectives and possessors, acting just like nouns.

form.instruction:
In the tree structure given at the beginning of
Simple and Possessed Nominal Phrases, we will assume for your language that pronouns, demonstratives, quantifiers and numbers can fill the NP position, like in English, because they can be modified by degree words, demonstratives, articles, relative clauses and PPs, but not by possessors or adjectives.

In the tree structure given at the beginning of
Simple and Possessed Nominal Phrases, we will assume for your language that pronouns, demonstratives, quantifiers and numbers can fill the N position, because they can be modified by all the same categories as nouns can.

In the tree structure given at the beginning of
Simple and Possessed Nominal Phrases, we will assume for your language that pronouns, demonstratives, quantifiers and numbers can fill the DP position, because they must stand alone in the place of a whole nominal phrase.
